resources.string: A person uses 20L every day, getting the water required for a person to live is hard.
Dirty water is bad. But puddles of dirty water is better than no water.
"800 children under five years of age die every day from diarrhea due to lack of safe water, sanitation and basic hygiene."

"According to the UN, the required amount of water to ensure basic human needs such as drinking, cooking and cleaning is 20 – 50 litres per person each day. A Norwegian citizen uses on average 200 litres of water per day. That is 20 times the daily usage of a villager in Kenya."

"Polluted water is one of the main causes of human disease, and the problem is most severe in poor areas. Typhoid fever, cholera, diphtheria, diarrhoea and hepatitis are examples of diseases that are transmitted through polluted drinking water."

"Clean drinking water is part of the UN’s sustainable development goals and reads: “Ensure access to water and sanitation for all.” This goal exists because of the fact that millions of people die each year of diseases due to the lack of access to clean drinking water and good sanitation. Most of these people are children."

"In 1992, the UN General Assembly decided that the 22nd of March should be the World Water Day. Every year, UN Water (the unit coordinating UN related work on water and sanitation) decide on a new theme for the World Water Day. In 2016, the theme was “Water and Jobs.”"
